Define a Cryptol module named AE that contains the following definitions and specifications: (1) A parameter section declaring abstract value types A and K, numeric types n, and p. Define the constraint tagAmount, such that p and n are finite and n is at least tagAmount. A tweakable permutation over n-bit blocks keyed by K that consumes a record containing a nonce, an abstract state, and a 64-bit counter; a 64-bit cost increment; a block encryption transform that maps a record of one p·n-bit block and the running p·n-bit state to the next record of the same shape; a corresponding decryption transform; and a tag function that maps a key, a tweak record, and a p·n·p-length message stream to an n-bit tag. A function encrypt with a constraint on m: for any finite m, takes a key, a nonce, an initial abstract state A, and a message of m blocks of size p·n, and returns m·(p·n) bits followed by tagAmount bits. Specify that it: splits the message into m blocks; iteratively applies the encryption transform to each block using a tweak whose counter is the running cost (starting at 1 and increased by the cost increment per block) and threading the p·n-bit state; concatenates the resulting per-block ciphertexts; derives the authentication tag by applying the tag function to the key and the final p·n-bit state; and returns ciphertext concatenated with the tag truncated to tagAmount bits.

```cryptol
module AE where

parameter
  type A : *            type K : *            type n : #            type p : #            type tagAmount : #

  type constraint (fin p, fin n, n >= tagAmount)

    tweak_cipher : K -> { nonce : [n], state : A, z : [64] } -> [n] -> [n]

    Cost : [64]

  Enc : K -> { nonce : [n], state : A, z : [64] }
          -> { message : [p*n], state : [p*n] }
          -> { message : [p*n], state : [p*n] }
  Dec : K -> { nonce : [n], state : A, z : [64] }
          -> { message : [p*n], state : [p*n] }
          -> { message : [p*n], state : [p*n] }
  Tag : K -> { nonce : [n], state : A, z : [64] } -> [p*n] -> [n]

type Node       = { message : WorkBlock, state : State }

type WorkBlock  = [p*n]

type State      = [p*n]  
type Tweak      = { nonce : Nonce, state : A, z : Int }
type Nonce      = [n]

type Int = [64]

encrypt :
  {m} fin m => K -> Nonce -> A -> [m * (p * n)] -> [m * (p * n) + tagAmount]
encrypt key nonce state inputMsg = encMsg # tag

  where
  encMsg = join rest.0.message

  tag = take (Tag key (tweak (1 - final.1)) final.0.state)

  final = steps ! 0

  steps = [ ({ message = undefined, state = zero }, 1) ] # rest
  rest  = [ (Enc key (tweak v) { message = m, state = prev.state }, v + Cost)
          | (prev,v) <- steps
          | m        <- chunks
          ]

  chunks : [m] [p * n]
  chunks = split inputMsg

  tweak : Int -> Tweak
  tweak v = { nonce = nonce, state = state, z = v }
```

Define a Cryptol module named Karatsuba that contains the functions: kmult, make_atleast, and splitmult. Specify kmult as a polymorphic function with constraints fin limb, fin n, limb >= 6, n >= 1; it takes two n-bit sequences and returns their 2n-bit product. It must use a conditional: when n is at least limb, widen both operands to be at least limb bits by prefixing zeros and then call splitmult; otherwise, perform a direct multiplication on zero-extended operands. Specify make_atleast as a polymorphic helper over sizes n, m and element a with constraints fin n, fin m, Zero a; it takes an m-length sequence and returns a max(n,m)-length sequence by prefixing zeros. Specify splitmult as Karatsuba multiplication; split each operand at hi = n/2 (low = n - hi), recursively compute products of high and low halves and recombine by appropriate zero-padding and concatenation to yield a 2n-bit result. Define 4 properties splitmult_correct_tiny, splitmult_correct_small, splitmult_correct_medium, splitmult_correct_large, and splitmult_correct_huge asserting that, for operand widths 9, 11, 17, and 59 with limb 7, and width 511 with limb 63, the result of splitmult equals the product of the zero-extended operands.

```cryptol
module Karatsuba where

kmult : {limb,n} (fin n, fin limb, limb >= 6, n >= 1) => [n] -> [n] -> [2*n]

kmult x y =
 if `n >= (`limb : [max (width limb) (width n)]) then
   take (splitmult`{limb} (make_atleast`{limb} x) (make_atleast`{limb} y))
 else
   (zero#x)*(zero#y)

make_atleast : {n, m, a} (fin n, fin m, Zero a) => [m]a -> [max n m]a
make_atleast x = zero#x

splitmult : {limb,n} (fin n, fin limb, limb >= 6, n >= 6)
         => [n] -> [n] -> [2*n]

splitmult x y = (ac # bd) + (zero # ad_bc # (zero:[low]))
  where
   type hi  = n/2
   type low = n - hi

   (a,b) = splitAt`{hi} x
   (c,d) = splitAt`{hi} y

   ac : [2*hi]
   ac = kmult`{limb,hi} a c

   bd : [2*low]
   bd = kmult`{limb,low} b d

   a_b = (zext a) + (zext b)
   c_d = (zext c) + (zext d)

   ad_bc : [2*(low+1)]
   ad_bc = (kmult`{limb,low+1} a_b c_d) - (zext ac) - (zext bd)

property splitmult_correct_tiny (x:[9]) (y:[9]) =
  zext x * zext y == splitmult`{limb=7} x y

property splitmult_correct_small (x:[11]) (y:[11]) =
  zext x * zext y == splitmult`{limb=7} x y

property splitmult_correct_medium(x:[17]) (y:[17]) =
  zext x * zext y == splitmult`{limb=7} x y

property splitmult_correct_large (x:[59]) (y:[59]) =
  zext x * zext y == splitmult`{limb=7} x y

property splitmult_correct_huge (x:[511]) (y:[511]) =
  zext x * zext y == splitmult`{limb=63} x y
```

Define a Cryptol module named Test that imports Cipher and contains the following definitions: evktest, evttest, ekatest, dvktest, dvttest, dkatest. For each function, provide a type signature quantified over size variables ks, bs, n with the constraint that bs is finite. Each returns a sequence of length n of pairs (a bs-bit value and a Bit flag). The Bit flag indicates whether the computed result equals the provided expected value. Specify inputs and behavior precisely: (1) evktest takes a cipher instance, a length‑n sequence of (key: ks bits, expected ciphertext: bs bits) pairs, and a fixed plaintext (bs bits); for each pair, encrypt the fixed plaintext under the key and pair the produced ciphertext with its equality against the expected ciphertext. (2) evttest takes a cipher instance, a fixed key (ks bits), and a length‑n sequence of (plaintext: bs bits, expected ciphertext: bs bits) pairs; for each pair, encrypt the plaintext under the fixed key and compare to the expected ciphertext. (3) ekatest takes a cipher instance and a length‑n sequence of (key: ks bits, plaintext: bs bits, expected ciphertext: bs bits) triples; for each triple, encrypt and compare to the expected ciphertext. (4) dvktest takes a cipher instance, a length‑n sequence of (key: ks bits, ciphertext: bs bits) pairs, and a fixed plaintext (bs bits); for each pair, decrypt the ciphertext under the key and compare to the fixed plaintext. (5) dvttest takes a cipher instance, a fixed key (ks bits), and a length‑n sequence of (plaintext: bs bits, ciphertext: bs bits) pairs; for each pair, decrypt the ciphertext under the fixed key and compare to the plaintext. (6) dkatest takes a cipher instance and a length‑n sequence of (key: ks bits, plaintext: bs bits, ciphertext: bs bits) triples; for each triple, decrypt and compare to the plaintext.

```cryptol
module Test where
import Cipher

evktest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [n]([ks],[bs]), [bs]) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
evktest (cipher, vkeysCTs, PT) =
    [ (CT', CT' == CT) where CT' = cipher.encrypt Key PT
    | (Key, CT) <- vkeysCTs ]

evttest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [ks], [n]([bs],[bs])) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
evttest (cipher, Key, vtextPCTs) =
    [ (CT', CT' == CT) where CT' = cipher.encrypt Key PT
    | (PT, CT) <- vtextPCTs ]

ekatest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [n]([ks],[bs],[bs])) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
ekatest (cipher, kaKPCTs) =
    [ (CT', CT' == CT) where CT' = cipher.encrypt Key PT
    | (Key, PT, CT) <- kaKPCTs ]

dvktest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [n]([ks],[bs]), [bs]) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
dvktest (cipher, vkeysCTs, PT) =
    [ (PT', PT' == PT) where PT' = cipher.decrypt Key CT
    | (Key, CT) <- vkeysCTs ]

dvttest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [ks], [n]([bs],[bs])) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
dvttest (cipher, Key, vtextPCTs) =
    [ (PT', PT' == PT) where PT' = cipher.decrypt Key CT
    | (PT, CT) <- vtextPCTs ]

dkatest : {ks, bs, n} (fin bs)
       => (Cipher ks bs, [n]([ks],[bs],[bs])) -> [n]([bs], Bit)
dkatest (cipher, kaKPCTs) =
    [ (PT', PT' == PT) where PT' = cipher.decrypt Key CT
    | (Key, PT, CT) <- kaKPCTs ]
```

Define a module named Array that contains the following definitions: a primitive two-parameter type constructor representing an indexed array; primitive functions to construct a constant-filled array, read an element by index, write an element at an index producing a new array, test equality of two fixed-size arrays, copy a contiguous range from a source array to a destination array, set a contiguous range in an array to a single value, and test equality of two ranges from two arrays. Provide precise polymorphic type signatures for each, using bitvector index types of width n for fixed-size arrays and appropriate constraints ensuring n is finite and fits within the index type, and that the index type supports integral addition. Use universally quantified variables for element type, index type, and length, and clearly state all required class constraints. Do not provide implementations for the primitives beyond their type signatures.

```cryptol
module Array where

primitive type Array : * -> * -> *

primitive arrayConstant : {a, b} b -> (Array a b)
primitive arrayLookup : {a, b} (Array a b) -> a -> b
primitive arrayUpdate : {a, b} (Array a b) -> a -> b -> (Array a b)
primitive arrayEq : {n, a} (Array [n] a) -> (Array [n] a) -> Bool

primitive arrayCopy : {n, a} (Array [n] a) -> [n] -> (Array [n] a) -> [n] -> [n] -> (Array [n] a)

primitive arraySet : {n, a} (Array [n] a) -> [n] -> a -> [n] -> (Array [n] a)

primitive arrayRangeEqual : {n, a} (Array [n] a) -> [n] -> (Array [n] a) -> [n] -> [n] -> Bool

arrayRangeLookup : {a, b, n} (Integral a, fin n, LiteralLessThan n a) => (Array a b) -> a -> [n]b
arrayRangeLookup arr idx = res
  where
    res @ i = arrayLookup arr (idx + i)

arrayRangeUpdate : {a, b, n} (Integral a, fin n, LiteralLessThan n a) => (Array a b) -> a -> [n]b -> (Array a b)
arrayRangeUpdate arr idx vals = arrs ! 0
  where
    arrs = [arr] # [ arrayUpdate acc (idx + i) val | acc <- arrs | i <- [0 ..< n] | val <- vals ]
```

Define a Cryptol module named SuiteB that contains the following definitions, types, and constraints, preserving names and arities: (1) Type synonyms for AES key-size parameters representing the number of 32-bit words for 128-, 192-, and 256-bit keys; a type alias for a 4-by-32-bit AES round key; record types for parameterized encrypt/decrypt key schedules with fields for initial key, an array of k+5 round keys, and a final key. (2) Public functions that produce encryption/decryption schedules and paired schedules for each supported key size (128, 192, 256) by delegating to generic expansion helpers. (3) A block encryption function over 128-bit blocks parameterized by k that iteratively applies a primitive AES encryption round across the round keys; similarly, a block decryption function that uses the corresponding decrypt primitives and round-key order. (4) Private helpers: a generic encrypt-schedule expansion; a conversion from encrypt to decrypt schedule that reverses round keys and applies inverse mix-columns; a generic decrypt-schedule expansion and a pair-producing expansion. Include constraints that k is finite and between 4 and 8 inclusive. (5) Primitive declarations for AES round, final round, inverse mix-columns, and key expansion. (6) Public SHA-2 hash functions producing 224-, 256-, 384-, and 512-bit digests that pad an arbitrary-length bitvector, split into 16-word blocks of 32 or 64 bits. A Private SHA-2 helper for block size, number of blocks, padded size, a padding function, a block-splitting function, and primitive processors.

```cryptol
module SuiteB where

type AES128 = 4

type AES192 = 6

type AES256 = 8

type AESRoundKey = [4][32]

type AESEncryptKeySchedule k =
  { aesEncInitialKey : AESRoundKey
  , aesEncRoundKeys  : [k+5]AESRoundKey
  , aesEncFinalKey   : AESRoundKey
  }

type AESDecryptKeySchedule k =
  { aesDecInitialKey : AESRoundKey
  , aesDecRoundKeys  : [k+5]AESRoundKey
  , aesDecFinalKey   : AESRoundKey
  }

aes128EncryptSchedule : [128] -> AESEncryptKeySchedule AES128
aes128EncryptSchedule = aesExpandEncryptSchedule

aes128DecryptSchedule : [128] -> AESDecryptKeySchedule AES128
aes128DecryptSchedule = aesExpandDecryptSchedule

aes128Schedules : [128] -> (AESEncryptKeySchedule AES128, AESDecryptKeySchedule AES128)
aes128Schedules = aesExpandSchedules

aes192EncryptSchedule : [192] -> AESEncryptKeySchedule AES192
aes192EncryptSchedule = aesExpandEncryptSchedule

aes192DecryptSchedule : [192] -> AESDecryptKeySchedule AES192
aes192DecryptSchedule = aesExpandDecryptSchedule

aes192Schedules : [192] -> (AESEncryptKeySchedule AES192, AESDecryptKeySchedule AES192)
aes192Schedules = aesExpandSchedules

aes256EncryptSchedule : [256] -> AESEncryptKeySchedule AES256
aes256EncryptSchedule = aesExpandEncryptSchedule

aes256DecryptSchedule : [256] -> AESDecryptKeySchedule AES256
aes256DecryptSchedule = aesExpandDecryptSchedule

aes256Schedules : [256] -> (AESEncryptKeySchedule AES256, AESDecryptKeySchedule AES256)
aes256Schedules = aesExpandSchedules

aesEncryptBlock : {k} (fin k) => AESEncryptKeySchedule k -> [128] -> [128]
aesEncryptBlock schedule plaintext = rnf (join final)
  where
  final = (AESEncFinalRound (rds!0)) ^ schedule.aesEncFinalKey

  rds = [ schedule.aesEncInitialKey ^ split plaintext ] #
        [ AESEncRound r ^ rdk
        | rdk <- schedule.aesEncRoundKeys
        | r   <- rds
        ]

aesDecryptBlock : {k} (fin k) => AESDecryptKeySchedule k -> [128] -> [128]
aesDecryptBlock schedule cyphertext = rnf (join final)
  where
  final = (AESDecFinalRound (rds!0)) ^ schedule.aesDecFinalKey

  rds = [ split cyphertext ^ schedule.aesDecInitialKey ] #
        [ AESDecRound r ^ rdk
        | rdk <- schedule.aesDecRoundKeys
        | r   <- rds
        ]

private
    aesExpandEncryptSchedule : {k} (fin k, k >= 4, 8 >= k) => [k * 32] -> AESEncryptKeySchedule k
    aesExpandEncryptSchedule key = rnf
         { aesEncInitialKey = ks @  0
         , aesEncRoundKeys  = ks @@ [ 1 .. k+5 ]
         , aesEncFinalKey   = ks @  `(k+6)
         }
      where
      ks : [k+7]AESRoundKey
      ks = groupBy`{4} (AESKeyExpand`{k} (split key))

    aesEncToDecSchedule : {k} (fin k) => AESEncryptKeySchedule k -> AESDecryptKeySchedule k
    aesEncToDecSchedule enc = rnf
       { aesDecInitialKey = enc.aesEncFinalKey
       , aesDecRoundKeys  = map AESInvMixColumns (reverse (enc.aesEncRoundKeys))
       , aesDecFinalKey   = enc.aesEncInitialKey
       }

    aesExpandDecryptSchedule : {k} (fin k, k >= 4, 8 >= k) => [k * 32] -> AESDecryptKeySchedule k
    aesExpandDecryptSchedule key = aesEncToDecSchedule (aesExpandEncryptSchedule key)

    aesExpandSchedules : {k} (fin k, k >= 4, 8 >= k) => [k * 32] -> (AESEncryptKeySchedule k, AESDecryptKeySchedule k)
    aesExpandSchedules key = (encS, aesEncToDecSchedule encS)
      where encS = aesExpandEncryptSchedule key

    primitive AESEncRound      : [4][32] -> [4][32]
    primitive AESEncFinalRound : [4][32] -> [4][32]
    primitive AESDecRound      : [4][32] -> [4][32]
    primitive AESDecFinalRound : [4][32] -> [4][32]
    primitive AESInvMixColumns : [4][32] -> [4][32]
    primitive AESKeyExpand     : {k} (fin k, k >= 4, 8 >= k) => [k][32] -> [4*(k+7)][32]

sha224 : {L} (fin L) => [L] -> [224]
sha224 msg = join (processSHA2_224 (sha2blocks`{32} msg))

sha256 : {L} (fin L) => [L] -> [256]
sha256 msg = join (processSHA2_256 (sha2blocks`{32} msg))

sha384 : {L} (fin L) => [L] -> [384]
sha384 msg = join (processSHA2_384 (sha2blocks`{64} msg))

sha512 : {L} (fin L) => [L] -> [512]
sha512 msg = join (processSHA2_512 (sha2blocks`{64} msg))

private
    type sha2_block_size w = 16 * w
    type sha2_num_blocks w L = (L+1+2*w) /^ sha2_block_size w
    type sha2_padded_size w L = sha2_num_blocks w L * sha2_block_size w

    sha2pad : {w, L} (fin w, fin L, w >= 1) => [L] -> [sha2_padded_size w L]
    sha2pad M = rnf (M # 0b1 # zero # ((fromInteger `L) : [2*w]))

    sha2blocks : {w, L} (fin w, fin L, w >= 1) =>
      [L] -> [sha2_num_blocks w L][16][w]
    sha2blocks msg = [ split x | x <- split (sha2pad`{w} msg) ]

(3) A predicate that recognizes the projective identity (point at infinity) as those with zero z-coordinate while not allowing the trivial all-zero triple. (4) An equality predicate on projective points that returns true if both are the identity or, if both are non-identity, their affine coordinates are equal after converting from projective. (5) A function converting affine to projective by setting the z-coordinate to the multiplicative identity. (6) A function converting projective to affine by scaling x by the inverse square of z and y by the inverse cube of z, and raising an error when z is zero. (7) Converters between field elements and fixed-width bitvectors with constraints fin p, p ≥ 1, and fin a, using integer coercions. (8) Primitive declarations (no bodies) for point doubling, nonzero-point addition, scalar multiplication, and two-scalar multiplication, all over the field modulo p with prime p and p > 3. (10) Point addition that handles identity cases and otherwise delegates to the primitive nonzero addition, and subtraction defined as addition with the negated second operand. module PrimeEC where

type AffinePoint p =
  { x : Z p
  , y : Z p
  }

type ProjectivePoint p =
  { x : Z p
  , y : Z p
  , z : Z p
  }

ec_is_point_affine : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => Z p -> AffinePoint p -> Bit
ec_is_point_affine b S = S.y^^2 == S.x^^3 - (3*S.x) + b

ec_is_nonsingular : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => Z p -> Bit
ec_is_nonsingular b = (fromInteger 4) * a^^3 + (fromInteger 27) * b^^2 != 0
  where a = -3 : Z p

ec_is_identity : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => ProjectivePoint p -> Bit
ec_is_identity S = S.z == 0 /\ ~(S.x == 0 /\ S.y == 0)

ec_equal : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p -> Bit
ec_equal S T =
  (S.z == 0 /\ T.z == 0) \/
  (S.z != 0 /\ T.z != 0 /\ ec_affinify S == ec_affinify T)

ec_projectify : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => AffinePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p
ec_projectify R = { x = R.x, y = R.y, z = 1 }

ec_affinify : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => ProjectivePoint p -> AffinePoint p
ec_affinify S =
 if S.z == 0 then error "Cannot affinify the point at infinity" else R
    where
      R = {x = lambda^^2 * S.x, y = lambda^^3 * S.y }
      lambda = recip S.z

ZtoBV : {p, a} (fin p, p >= 1, fin a) => Z p -> [a]
ZtoBV x = fromInteger (fromZ x)

BVtoZ : {p, a} (fin p, p >= 1, fin a) => [a] -> Z p
BVtoZ x = fromInteger (toInteger x)

primitive ec_double : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p

primitive ec_add_nonzero : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p

ec_negate : {p} (prime p, p > 3) => ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p
ec_negate S = { x = S.x, y = -S.y, z = S.z }

ec_add : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p
ec_add S T =
  if S.z == 0 then T
   | T.z == 0 then S
   else R
 where R = ec_add_nonzero S T

ec_sub : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p
ec_sub S T = ec_add S U
 where U = { x = T.x, y = -T.y, z = T.z }

primitive ec_mult : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  Z p -> ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p

primitive ec_twin_mult : {p} (prime p, p > 3) =>
  Z p -> ProjectivePoint p -> Z p -> ProjectivePoint p -> ProjectivePoint p

 * Functional right fold.

 * foldr (-) 0 [1,2,3] = 0 - (1 - (2 - 3))
 */
foldr : {n, a, b} (fin n) => (a -> b -> b) -> b -> [n]a -> b
foldr f acc xs = foldl g acc (reverse xs)
  where g b a = f a b

/**
 * Functional right fold, with strict evaluation of the accumulator value.
 * The accumulator is reduced to weak head normal form at each step.
 *
 * foldr' (-) 0 [1,2,3] = 0 - (1 - (2 - 3))
 */
foldr' : {n, a, b} (fin n, Eq b) => (a -> b -> b) -> b -> [n]a -> b
foldr' f acc xs = foldl' g acc (reverse xs)
  where g b a = f a b

/**
 * Compute the sum of the values in the sequence.
 */
sum : {n, a} (fin n, Eq a, Ring a) => [n]a -> a
sum xs = foldl' (+) (fromInteger 0) xs

product : {n, a} (fin n, Eq a, Ring a) => [n]a -> a
product xs = foldl' (*) (fromInteger 1) xs

/**
 * Scan left is like a foldl that also emits the intermediate values.
 */
primitive scanl : {n, a, b}  (a -> b -> a) -> a -> [n]b -> [1+n]a

/**
 * Scan right is like a foldr that also emits the intermediate values.
 */
scanr : {n, a, b} (fin n) => (a -> b -> b) -> b -> [n]a -> [1+n]b
scanr f acc xs = reverse (scanl (\a b -> f b a) acc (reverse xs))

/**
 * Repeat a value.
 */
repeat : {n, a} a -> [n]a
repeat x = [ x | _ <- zero : [n] ]

/**
 * 'elem x xs' returns true if x is equal to a value in xs.
 */
elem : {n, a} (fin n, Eq a) => a -> [n]a -> Bit
elem a xs = any (\x -> x == a) xs

/**
 * Create a list of tuples from two lists.
 */
zip : {n, a, b} [n]a -> [n]b -> [n](a, b)
zip xs ys = [(x,y) | x <- xs | y <- ys]

/**
 * Create a list by applying the function to each pair of elements in the input.
 */
zipWith : {n, a, b, c} (a -> b -> c) -> [n]a -> [n]b -> [n]c
zipWith f xs ys = [f x y | x <- xs | y <- ys]

/**
 * Transform a function into uncurried form.
 */
uncurry : {a, b, c} (a -> b -> c) -> (a, b) -> c
uncurry f = \(a, b) -> f a b

/**
 * Transform a function into curried form.
 */
curry : {a, b, c} ((a, b) -> c) -> a -> b -> c
curry f = \a b -> f (a, b)

/**
 * Map a function iteratively over a seed value, producing an infinite
 * list of successive function applications.
 */
iterate : {a} (a -> a) -> a -> [inf]a
iterate f z = scanl (\x _ -> f x) z (zero:[inf]())

In Cryptol, define enumerations for Maybe a (with absence or a value), Either a b (with left or right value), Foo a (three nullary variants and one carrying an 8-bit word and a value), and Letter (three symbols). Provide equality predicates maybeEqual, eitherEqual, fooEqual with types returning Bit and using Eq constraints where needed to compare only when constructors match and, for parameterized cases, using the underlying equality. Define mapping functions: maybeMap to apply a function only to a present value; eitherMapLeft and eitherMapRight to map over left or right, and eitherMapBoth to map both in one pass; fooMap to map only the value field of the binary Foo constructor, leaving the 8-bit field and other variants unchanged; letterRotate to cycle the three letters. Define a property that for Maybe [8], mapping (+1) twice equals mapping (+2) once, compared via maybeEqual. Define a property that for Either [8] [8], applying (+1) to the right then to the left equals mapping both once, compared via eitherEqual. Define a property that for Foo [8], mapping (+1) twice equals mapping (+2) once, compared via fooEqual. Define a property that for Letter, rotating three times yields the original value, checked by letterEqual.

```cryptol
enum Maybe a = Nothing | Just a

maybeEqual : {a} (Eq a) => Maybe a -> Maybe a -> Bit
maybeEqual m1 m2 =
  case m1 of
    Just x1 ->
      case m2 of
        Just x2 -> x1 == x2
        Nothing -> False
    Nothing ->
      case m2 of
        Just x2 -> False
        Nothing -> True

maybeMap : {a, b} (a -> b) -> Maybe a -> Maybe b
maybeMap f m =
  case m of
    Just x  -> Just (f x)
    Nothing -> Nothing

maybeMapProp : Maybe [8] -> Bit
property maybeMapProp m =
  maybeEqual
    (maybeMap (\x -> x + 1) (maybeMap (\x -> x + 1) m))
    (maybeMap (\x -> x + 2) m)

enum Either a b = Left a | Right b

eitherEqual : {a, b} (Eq a, Eq b) => Either a b -> Either a b -> Bit
eitherEqual e1 e2 =
  case e1 of
    Left x1 ->
      case e2 of
        Left x2  -> x1 == x2
        Right y2 -> False
    Right y1 ->
      case e2 of
        Left x2  -> False
        Right y2 -> y1 == y2

eitherMapLeft : {a, a', b} (a -> a') -> Either a b -> Either a' b
eitherMapLeft f e =
  case e of
    Left x  -> Left (f x)
    Right y -> Right y

eitherMapRight : {a, b, b'} (b -> b') -> Either a b -> Either a b'
eitherMapRight g e =
  case e of
    Left x  -> Left x
    Right y -> Right (g y)

eitherMapBoth : {a, a', b, b'} (a -> a') -> (b -> b') -> Either a b -> Either a' b'
eitherMapBoth f g e =
  case e of
    Left x  -> Left (f x)
    Right y -> Right (g y)

eitherMapProp : Either [8] [8] -> Bit
property eitherMapProp e =
  eitherEqual
    (eitherMapLeft (\x -> x + 1) (eitherMapRight (\y -> y + 1) e))
    (eitherMapBoth (\x -> x + 1) (\y -> y + 1) e)

enum Foo a = Bar | Baz | Quux | Fred [8] a

fooEqual : {a} (Eq a) => Foo a -> Foo a -> Bit
fooEqual f1 f2 =
  case f1 of
    Bar ->
      case f2 of
        Bar        -> True
        Baz        -> False
        Quux       -> False
        Fred y1 y2 -> False
    Baz ->
      case f2 of
        Bar        -> False
        Baz        -> True
        Quux       -> False
        Fred y1 y2 -> False
    Quux ->
      case f2 of
        Bar        -> False
        Baz        -> False
        Quux       -> True
        Fred y1 y2 -> False
    Fred x1 x2 ->
      case f2 of
        Bar        -> False
        Baz        -> False
        Quux       -> False
        Fred y1 y2 -> (x1 == y1) /\ (x2 == y2)

fooMap : {a, b} (a -> b) -> Foo a -> Foo b
fooMap f ff =
  case ff of
    Bar      -> Bar
    Baz      -> Baz
    Quux     -> Quux
    Fred x y -> Fred x (f y)

fooMapProp : Foo [8] -> Bit
property fooMapProp f =
  fooEqual
    (fooMap (\x -> x + 1) (fooMap (\x -> x + 1) f))
    (fooMap (\x -> x + 2) f)

enum Letter = A | B | C

letterEqual : Letter -> Letter -> Bit
letterEqual l1 l2 =
  case l1 of
    A ->
      case l2 of
        A -> True
        B -> False
        C -> False
    B ->
      case l2 of
        A -> False
        B -> True
        C -> False
    C ->
      case l2 of
        A -> False
        B -> False
        C -> True

letterRotate : Letter -> Letter
letterRotate l =
  case l of
    A -> B
    B -> C
    C -> A

letterRotateProp : Letter -> Bit
property letterRotateProp l =
  letterEqual l (letterRotate (letterRotate (letterRotate l)))
```

mct_ecb_encrypt_192 : [192] -> [128] -> [100](AESTestVector 192)
mct_ecb_encrypt_192 initialKey initialPt = vs
  where
  vs@i = { key = keys@i, plaintext=pts@(i*1000), ciphertext=cts@(i*1000 + 999) }

  pts : [100*1000][128]
  pts = [initialPt] # take cts

  cts : [100*1000][128]
  cts@i = aesEncryptBlock (schedules@(i/1000)) (pts@i)

  keys : [100][192]
  keys = [initialKey] # [ k ^ ((drop`{64} (xs!1)) # xs!0)
                        | xs <- take`{99} (groupBy`{1000} cts)
                        | k <- keys
                        ]

  schedules : [100](AESEncryptKeySchedule AES192)
  schedules = map aes192EncryptSchedule keys

mct_ecb_decrypt_192 : [192] -> [128] -> [100](AESTestVector 192)
mct_ecb_decrypt_192 initialKey initialCt = vs
  where
  vs@i = { key = keys@i, ciphertext=cts@(i*1000), plaintext=pts@(i*1000 + 999) }

  cts : [100*1000][128]
  cts = [initialCt] # take pts

  pts : [100*1000][128]
  pts@i = aesDecryptBlock (schedules@(i/1000)) (cts@i)

  keys : [100][192]
  keys = [initialKey] # [ k ^ ((drop`{64} (xs!1)) # xs!0)
                        | xs <- take`{99} (groupBy`{1000} pts)
                        | k <- keys
                        ]

  schedules : [100](AESDecryptKeySchedule AES192)
  schedules = map aes192DecryptSchedule keys

Using the elliptic-curve utilities from the PrimeEC library, define the following over the curve parameter 7: a constant named zro with type ProjectivePoint 7 representing the projective neutral element (point at infinity). A property twin_mult_zro that, for arbitrary scalars j and k, verifies that twin scalar multiplication of j and k by the neutral element yields the neutral element. Define a property twin_mult_zro1 that, for arbitrary scalars j and k and any projective point S on the same curve, verifies that twin scalar multiplication with the first input point equal to the neutral element equals single scalar multiplication of S by k. Define a property twin_mult_zro2 that verifies the symmetric case where the second input point is the neutral element equals single scalar multiplication of S by j. Define a property twin_mult_same that verifies twin scalar multiplication applied to the same point in both slots equals the elliptic-curve addition of the separate scalar multiples by j and k. Define a property twin_mult_neg that verifies twin scalar multiplication where the second input point is the negation of the first equals the elliptic-curve subtraction of the corresponding scalar multiples.

```cryptol
import PrimeEC

zro : ProjectivePoint 7
zro = { x = 1, y = 1, z = 0 }

property twin_mult_zro j k =
  ec_equal`{7} (ec_twin_mult j zro k zro) zro

property twin_mult_zro1 j k S =
  ec_equal`{7} (ec_twin_mult j zro k S) (ec_mult k S)

property twin_mult_zro2 j k S =
  ec_equal`{7} (ec_twin_mult j S k zro) (ec_mult j S)

property twin_mult_same j k S =
  ec_equal`{7} (ec_twin_mult j S k S) (ec_add (ec_mult j S) (ec_mult k S))

property twin_mult_neg j k S =
  ec_equal`{7} (ec_twin_mult j S k (ec_negate S)) (ec_sub (ec_mult j S) (ec_mult k S))
```

Define four Cryptol properties named wordUpdate, wordUpdate2, wordUpdateEnd, and wordUpdateEnd2. Each property takes three parameters: a 16-bit word x, an 8-bit index y, and a single bit b, and is conditioned on the precondition y < 16. For wordUpdate, define a property that verifies that updating bit position y counted from the most-significant end equals: if b is 1, the bitwise OR of x with a mask containing a single 1 at the most-significant position shifted right by y; otherwise, the bitwise AND of x with the bitwise complement of that mask. For wordUpdate2, define a property that verifies that the same update equals reconstructing the 16-bit word by iterating indices 0 through 15. For wordUpdateEnd verifies that updating bit position y counted from the least-significant end equals: if b is 1, the bitwise OR of x with a mask containing a single 1 at the least-significant position shifted left by y; otherwise, the bitwise AND of x with the bitwise complement of that mask. For wordUpdateEnd2 verifies that the same least-significant-end update equals reconstructing the word by enumerating all bit positions.

```cryptol
property wordUpdate (x:[16]) (y:[8]) (b:Bit) =
  y < 16 ==> update x y b == if b then x || msk else x && ~msk

 where
 msk = 0b1000000000000000 >> y

property wordUpdate2 (x:[16]) (y:[8]) (b:Bit) =
  y < 16 ==> update x y b == x'

 where
 x' = [ if i == y then b else x@i | i <- [0 .. 15] ]

property wordUpdateEnd (x:[16]) (y:[8]) (b:Bit) =
  y < 16 ==> updateEnd x y b == if b then x || msk else x && ~msk

 where
 msk = 0b0000000000000001 << y

property wordUpdateEnd2 (x:[16]) (y:[8]) (b:Bit) =
  y < 16 ==> updateEnd x y b == x'

 where
 x' = [ if i == y then b else x!i | i <- reverse [0 .. 15] ]
```

Define Cryptol properties with the following names and meanings, using universal quantification over the stated types: QaddUnit, QaddComm, QaddAssoc, Qneg, QmulUnit, QmulComm, QmulAssoc, Qdistrib (all over Rational) to capture additive/multiplicative identities, commutativity, associativity, additive inverse, and distributivity. Qrecip (Rational) to assert that either the value is zero or multiplying by its reciprocal yields the multiplicative identity. QdivisionEquiv (Rational, Rational) to state that rational division equals multiplication by the reciprocal, guarded so the divisor may be zero without causing a partial operation. Ordering properties over Rational: QordEquiv1 (<= equivalent to not greater-than), QordEquiv2 (<= equivalent to equality or <), QordTrans (transitivity of <), QordIrreflexive (no value is < itself), QordExclusive (cannot be both x<y and y<x), Qtrichotomy (exactly one of <, ==, > holds in disjunction form), QordCompatible (addition preserves < with the same addend), QordPositive (product is positive when both factors are positive). Qdense (Rational) to assert density: if one value is strictly less than another, then their average lies strictly between them; define a local midpoint as the average using rational division by two. Integer/Rational bridging: intDivDown (Integer, Integer) to assert that either the divisor is zero or the rationalized result of truncating integer division is less than or equal to the exact rational ratio. Floor and ceiling correctness over Rational and Integer: floorCorrect1 (floor is a lower bound), floorCorrect2 (any integer lower bound is ≤ floor), ceilingCorrect1 (ceiling is an upper bound), ceilingCorrect2 (any integer upper bound is ≥ ceiling). Use fromInteger, floor, ceiling, ratio, recip, negate, logical implication, disjunction, conjunction, and negation. Guard all potentially partial operations (e.g., reciprocal/division by zero).

```cryptol
property QaddUnit (x : Rational) =
  x + 0 == x

property QaddComm (x:Rational) (y:Rational) =
  x + y == y + x

property QaddAssoc (x:Rational) (y:Rational) (z:Rational) =
  x + (y + z) == (x + y) + z

property Qneg (x: Rational) = x + negate x == 0

property QmulUnit (x : Rational) =
  x * 1 == x

property QmulComm (x:Rational) (y:Rational) =
  x * y == y * x

property QmulAssoc (x:Rational) (y:Rational) (z:Rational) =
  x * (y * z) == (x * y) * z

property Qdistrib (x:Rational) (y:Rational) (z:Rational) =
  x * (y + z) == x*y + x*z

property Qrecip (x: Rational) = x == 0 \/ x * recip x == 1

property QdivisionEquiv (x : Rational) (y : Rational) =
  y == 0 \/ x /. y == x * (recip y)

property QordEquiv1 (x : Rational) (y : Rational) =
  (x <= y) == ~(y < x)

property QordEquiv2 (x : Rational) (y : Rational) =
  (x <= y) == (x == y \/ x < y)

property QordTrans (x : Rational) (y : Rational) (z : Rational) =
  x < y ==> y < z ==> x < z

property QordIrreflexive (x : Rational) =
  ~(x < x)

property QordExclusive (x : Rational) (y:Rational) =
  ~(x < y) || ~(y < x) 

property Qtrichotomy (x : Rational) (y : Rational) =
  x < y \/ x == y \/ x > y

property QordCompatible (x : Rational) (y : Rational) (z:Rational) =
  x < y ==> x+z < y+z

property QordPositive (x : Rational) (y : Rational) =
  0 < x ==> 0 < y ==> 0 < x*y

property Qdense (x : Rational) (y : Rational) = x < y ==> x < mid /\ mid < y
  where
  mid = (x + y) /. 2

property intDivDown (x : Integer) (y:Integer) =
  y == 0 \/ fromInteger (x / y) <= ratio x y

property floorCorrect1 (x:Rational) =
  fromInteger (floor x) <= x

property floorCorrect2 (x:Rational) (y:Integer) =
  fromInteger y <= x ==>
  y <= floor x

property ceilingCorrect1 (x:Rational) =
  fromInteger (ceiling x) >= x

property ceilingCorrect2 (x:Rational) (y:Integer) =
  fromInteger y >= x ==>
  y >= ceiling x
```

Write a Cryptol specification that defines parametric predicates and helpers for verifying bit-vector division and modulo, along with 8-bit properties. Use n-bit words throughout, with fin n for all definitions and n >= 1 where signed arithmetic is used. Define three unsigned predicates over two n-bit operands: one asserting the Euclidean identity for division and remainder when the divisor is nonzero; one characterizing the unsigned quotient as the integer-converted result matching the floor of the rational quotient of the integer-converted operands; and one bounding the remainder between zero (inclusive) and the divisor (exclusive). Define helpers for signed arithmetic: an n-bit absolute-value function using signed comparison and two’s-complement negation; a function that converts an n-bit two’s-complement value to an unbounded Integer, branching on the sign to produce the correct signed magnitude; and constants for the most negative and most positive n-bit two’s-complement values. Define five signed predicates over two n-bit operands: one asserting the Euclidean identity using signed division and remainder when the divisor is nonzero; one stating that, for nonzero divisor, either the overflow case of dividing the most negative value by −1 holds, or the truncated rational quotient of the integer-converted operands equals the integer-converted signed quotient; one bounding the magnitude of the signed remainder to be nonnegative and strictly less than the absolute value of the divisor; one asserting the remainder’s sign matches the dividend’s sign for nonzero divisor; and one combining the standard identity remainder = dividend − quotient × divisor with the sign implications for the remainder. Finally, define properties named d1, c1, m1, d2, c2, m2, m3, and sdiv that assert the 8-bit instances of these unsigned and signed predicates, respectively.

```cryptol
bvdiv_euc : {n} (fin n) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvdiv_euc x y = y != 0 ==> (x/y)*y + x%y == x

bvdiv_char : {n} (fin n) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvdiv_char x y = y != 0 ==> floor r == toInteger (x / y)
  where
    r = ratio (toInteger x) (toInteger y)

bvdiv_mod : {n} (fin n) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvdiv_mod x y = y != 0 ==> (0 <= m /\ m < y)
  where
    m = x%y

sabs : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n]
sabs x = if x <=$ 0 then negate x else x

toSignedInteger : {n} (fin n, n >=1 ) => [n] -> Integer
toSignedInteger x = if x <=$ 0 then negate (toInteger (negate x)) else toInteger x

minint : {n} (fin n, n >= 1) => [n]
minint = 0b1 # zero

maxint : {n} (fin n, n >= 1) => [n]
maxint = ~minint

bvsdiv_euc : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvsdiv_euc x y = y != 0 ==> (x/$y)*y + x%$y == x

bvsdiv_char : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvsdiv_char x y = y != 0 ==> overflow \/ trunc r == toSignedInteger (x /$ y)
  where
    overflow = x == minint /\ y == (-1)
    r = ratio (toSignedInteger x) (toSignedInteger y)

bvsdiv_mod : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvsdiv_mod x y = y != 0 ==> (0 <= m /\ m < sabs y)
  where
    m = sabs (x%$y)

bvsdiv_mod_sign : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvsdiv_mod_sign x y =
  y != 0 ==>
    if x >=$ 0 then x%$y >=$ 0 else x%$y <=$ 0

bvsdiv_doc_properties : {n} (fin n, n>=1) => [n] -> [n] -> Bit
bvsdiv_doc_properties x y =
  y != 0 ==>
    (x %$ y == x - (x /$ y) * y) /\
    (x >=$ 0 ==> x%$y >=$ 0) /\
    (x <=$ 0 ==> x%$y <=$ 0)

property d1 = bvdiv_euc`{8}
property c1 = bvdiv_char`{8}
property m1 = bvdiv_mod`{8}

property d2 = bvsdiv_euc`{8}
property c2 = bvsdiv_char`{8}
property m2 = bvsdiv_mod`{8}
property m3 = bvsdiv_mod_sign`{8}
property sdiv = bvsdiv_doc_properties`{8}
```

Write a Cryptol specification that models dense univariate polynomials over a ring and verifies their evaluation laws. Define a properties that assert, over integers, evaluating the monic quadratic with only a squared term at an input equals the square of that input, for degree-5 integer polynomials and any integer input, evaluating the sum equals the sum of evaluations, and for degree-5 integer polynomials and any integer input, evaluating the product equals the product of evaluations. Define the helper functions and types needed to implement these properties.

```cryptol
newtype Poly n a = { coeffs : [n+1]a }

evalPoly : {n, a} (fin n, Ring a) => Poly n a -> a -> a
evalPoly p x = foldl (+) zero terms
  where
    terms = [ c*a | c <- p.coeffs | a <- xs ]
    xs    = [fromInteger 1]#[ x*a | a <- xs ]

polyConst : {n, a} (fin n, Ring a) => a -> Poly n a
polyConst a = Poly { coeffs = [a]#zero }

polyAdd : {n, a} (fin n, Ring a) => Poly n a -> Poly n a -> Poly n a
polyAdd p1 p2 = Poly { coeffs = zipWith (+) p1.coeffs p2.coeffs }

polyMul : {n1, n2, a} (fin n1, fin n2, Ring a) =>
  Poly n1 a -> Poly n2 a -> Poly (n1+n2) a
polyMul p1 p2 = foldl polyAdd (polyConst zero) ps
  where
    ps : [n1+1](Poly (n1+n2) a)
    ps@i = Poly{ coeffs = scaleAndShift i }

    scaleAndShift i =
      ([ p1.coeffs@i * c | c <- p2.coeffs ] # zero) >> i

property polySquare (x:Integer) =
  evalPoly (Poly { coeffs = [0,0,1] }) x == x * x

property polyAddEval x (p1:Poly 5 Integer) (p2:Poly 5 Integer) =
  evalPoly (polyAdd p1 p2) x == evalPoly p1 x + evalPoly p2 x

property polyMulEval x (p1:Poly 5 Integer) (p2:Poly 5 Integer) =
  evalPoly (polyMul p1 p2) x == evalPoly p1 x * evalPoly p2 x
```
